script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I have to start with a mystery that's haunted readers for years. The Bible opens with 'In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth' from Genesis 1:1. But Moses 1 doesn't begin there—what if I told you it starts with a vision that reveals what existed before that 'beginning,' and why God created everything in the first place?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, you've hit on something profound. The Come Follow Me introduction points out that Moses 1 gives context for the Creation, addressing fundamental questions: Who is God? Who are we? What is God's work, and our place in it? Notice how it frames the entire Old Testament study.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly, and Moses asks the Lord, 'Be merciful unto thy servant, O God, and tell me concerning this earth, and the inhabitants thereof, and also the heavens' in Moses 1:36. But before answering that, God declares something about Moses's identity. Wait, what does He say first?

script.speaker: David
script.text: In Moses 1:4, God says to Moses, 'And thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten; and mine Only Begotten is and shall be the Savior.' Then in verse 6, 'And I have a work for thee, Moses, my son; and thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.' This sets up a divine identity that Satan immediately challenges.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's fascinating. So God affirms Moses as a son, like Christ, with a divine work. But hold on—Satan shows up right after this glory-filled vision. What does Satan say in Moses 1:12?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Satan says, 'Moses, son of man, worship me.' It's a counterfeit, stripping away the divine sonship. The Come Follow Me manual highlights this pattern: God declares your true identity as a child of God, while Satan confuses it.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: A pattern already. And President Russell M. Nelson taught, 'If the Lord were speaking to you directly, the first thing He would make sure you understand is your true identity.' So this isn't just ancient—it's for us. But how does Moses respond to Satan's temptation?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Moses resists by remembering his divine experience. In verses 13-26, he commands Satan, invoking God's power. Verse 20: 'Get thee hence, Satan; deceive me not.' Finally, at the word of God, angels come and cast Satan out. This shows spiritual experiences don't exempt us from temptation—Satan attacks them.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I need to understand this deeper. What counterfeits does Satan use, as in Moses 1:13-18? And how can we spot them today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Satan offers fake power and glory, like artificial plants or baby dolls that look real but aren't. He tempts with counterfeits of God's truth. Moses sees through it by relying on the Lord, as in verses 24-26: 'the Lord... called upon God... and the glory of God was upon Moses.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Remarkable. Now, after this battle, God shows Moses His works. Moses says in 1:30, 'Tell me... why these things are so.' What's the Lord's response?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here's where it gets powerful. In Moses 1:39, 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' Immortality is resurrection through Christ; eternal life is exaltation. This ties directly to our premortal origins.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Premortal—leading to Abraham 3. So after identity and God's work, we get the vision of spirits before the world was. David, trace this for me across these chapters.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely. Abraham 3:22-28 reveals we lived as spirits 'before the world was.' God organized intelligences, chose noble ones like Abraham, Jesus, us—to 'go down... and... prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's the plan right there. Notice the pattern: God declares identity to Moses, shows purpose, reveals premortal council in Abraham. But from multiple perspectives—God's to Moses, Abraham's vision, even Satan's counterfeit.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, multi-perspective. Ancient Israel's view might see Moses as lawgiver, but Restoration view through JST shows divine sonship. Abraham adds premortal layer. And modern prophets like President Nelson echo: 'The way you think about who you really are affects almost every decision you will ever make.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never saw how tightly these connect. So God's work in Moses 1:39—to bring eternal life—links to Abraham 3:25, where we prove ourselves for eternal truths.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. Hold that question: how does Christ fit? Abraham 3:24-26 shows the Savior chosen in premortal council to redeem us, making immortality and eternal life possible.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Building tension here. Now, for historical context— these are visions like ancient prophets had, but the JST makes them immediate. What cultural insight makes Moses's temptation feel real?

script.speaker: David
script.text: In ancient Near East, visions often followed glory encounters, with adversarial spirits tempting—like in other seer accounts. But Moses 1 shows the power of invoking Jehovah's name, as angels minister. It feels real because Satan uses familiar tactics: doubt your experience.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's vivid. Resolving our opening mystery: Moses 1 frames creation because before the beginning was premortal life, God's council, our divine potential.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly! The 'beginning' of Genesis is earth's creation, but Moses 1 and Abraham 3 reveal the premortal 'beginning' of our story. God starts with identity to prepare us.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Satisfying. Now hidden connections—compare God's words in Moses 1:4 and 6 with Satan's in 1:12. What shifts everything?

script.speaker: David
script.text: God: 'similitude of mine Only Begotten,' 'my son.' Satan: 'son of man'—reducing to mortal. Come Follow Me says look for this pattern: God elevates, Satan confuses.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And link to Abraham 3:22: 'These I will make my rulers.' We're noble spirits. Cross-reference to plan of salvation—premortal to proving here.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Watch this: Moses 1:39's 'immortality and eternal life' fulfills Abraham 3:26's redemption through Christ. Prophetic echo in Nelson: know your identity to make eternal choices.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Profound. Another connection: Moses resists by prayer and God's name—verses 20-22. Parallels Christ's temptations in Matthew 4.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Spot on. What most people miss: Satan's defeat in Moses 1:26 by 'the power of the Only Begotten' foreshadows temple covenants of protection.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: This changes how I read premortal life. Now modern application: how does Abraham 3:25's 'prove them' apply today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: We prove by choices reflecting identity. Nelson says list choices because you're a child of God first. In daily life, when tempted, recall Moses: 'Who art thou?'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: For families—Come Follow Me suggests mirror activity: 'I am a child of God' from Moses 1:4. Then compare to Satan's message.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Perfect for children. Act out resisting like Moses—pray, command in Christ's name. Ties to Abraham 3: sing 'I Will Follow God’s Plan.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Teaching tip: Use Gospel Art like 'Moses Sees Jehovah' to visualize identity declaration.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And for deeper study, list truths from Abraham 3:22-28 about self and Christ. Why valuable? Changes how we treat ourselves and others.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, trace the pattern further: divine identity across dispensations—Moses, Abraham, Restoration.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Moses dispensation: law with identity anchor. Abraham: covenant promise to noble spirits. Restoration: JST reveals it plainly. Modern: prophets urge it as primary identifier.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Pattern recognition mastery. Now contradiction resolution: Powerful vision, yet immediate temptation. Reveals truth: testimony needs constant guarding.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes—spiritual highs don't prevent tests. Moses overcomes by truth: 'I am a son of God.' Applies to us resisting counterfeits.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Hebrew insight? 'Similitude' implies likeness to Christ—divine potential.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, from Latin via JST, but evokes image of God. Abraham 3 adds intelligences organized—eternal progression hint.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Another layer: God's work 1:39 connects to premortal purpose. Worlds without number, yet personal work for each.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Personalized plan. Abraham 3:24-26: Christ as Redeemer central to proving.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Modern convergence: Nelson's devotional mirrors Moses 1—first truth is identity.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And 'Choices for Eternity' section reinforces. Strategy for teachers: Start lessons with identity affirmation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: For youth: Discuss fake versions Satan uses, like in manual.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Then spontaneous teaching at meals: How did you resist today, like Moses?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Children's activity: Key words in Abraham 3—'spirits,' 'prove,' draw pictures.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Practice responses to choices, Savior's help if wrong.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, one more connection: Hymns 'I Am a Child of God' echoes Moses 1.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And videos like 'Our True Identity.' Builds web.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: This week's content unlocks eternal perspective. From mystery of 'before the beginning' to daily choices.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Generational: Ancient covenants to modern discipleship.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Invitation: Ponder Moses 1:4-6. Make list of choices from divine identity, as Nelson suggests.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Read Abraham 3:22-28, list truths. See your premortal nobility.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Resist counterfeits like Moses. Your true identity changes everything.

script.speaker: David
script.text: God's work includes you. Prove faithful for eternal life.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Thanks, David. Listeners, dive into these scriptures this week.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Until next time, know who you are—a child of God.
